He started his cell phone repair business in 2009 by renting a counter in a cell phone store. He's one of the few people in the store who has technical education, which gives him an advantage over competitors. He is a sharp and hardworking man who says, "Now cell phones are getting advanced. Therefore, my equipment is not able to fix them." He is requesting 700,000 MNT to buy spare parts for his phone repair center.

loans.use: To buy spare parts for phone repair

loans.name: Mary's Group

texts.en:
Mary's group is comprised of five hard-working women. Mary is 20 years old and lives in the town of Natete in the Kampala North region of Uganda. She is single and has one child. For the past three years, Mary has been working hard to manage her health clinic, which sells medicine. 

To help expand her business, Mary has requested a loan of 200,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more medicine for resale, which will help Mary to generate greater profits. She intends to use those profits to buy new clothes for herself. Mary hopes that in the future she will be able to build a new house. 

Mary is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training. The ELA program has increased Mary's future prospects by helping her to learn new games like netball.

loans.use: to buy more medicine for resale

loans.name: Metameta Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Metameta Group in Western Kenya! Dorcas is the facilitator of the Metameta group. This group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Dorcas takes care of five children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and because One Acre Fund has the best prices. In the recent 2011 season, Dorcas had very good maize yield, harvesting 10 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Ace Fund, Dorcas was only able to harvest 9 bags of maize on 1 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Dorcas and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Dorcas will save for the future and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Metameta group will each plant  between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

In the photograph above, Dorcas and her group members are pictured.

loans.use: To source farming inputs such as seeds and fertilizer at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Hadijah

texts.en:
Hadijah is 21 years old and lives in the town of Natete in Uganda's Kampala North region. She is married and has two children, both of whom are enrolled in school. For the last three years, she has worked hard at her business, which consists of selling clothes. To help expand her business, she has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. She will use the loan to buy more clothes to sell, and use the additional income to increase her profits and pay her children's school fees. Her goal for the future is to continue expanding her business. 

Hadijah is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training. The ELA program has increased Hadijah's prospects by helping her improve her business.

loans.use: to buy more clothes to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Jasmin Group!

texts.en: Jasmin is 19 years old and lives in Poblacion, Sapang Dalaga with her husband and child. She earns about PHP 2,500 a month by raising livestock, and is applying for a loan for PHP 14,000 to buy a new cow. She has been a member of PMPC for one year and leads a two-person loan group.  Although the members borrow as a group, each person has her own business.

loans.use: To purchase a cow

loans.name: Consessa

texts.en: Consessa is married and has three children between the ages of 1 and 8. Her husband is a home builder. She sells vegetables in a market where she has been working for the last 10 years. Consessa would like a loan to expand the types of vegetables she sells in her store. She would like to use any profits to renovate her house.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables for resale

loans.name: Huruma Group

texts.en:
Teresia is the facilitator of Huruma group. Teresia and her group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Teresia takes care of four children at home.She joined One Acre Fund due to One Acre Fund’s best prices and in order to ensure food security for her family and later educate them. In the recent 2011 season, Teresia had a very good maize yield harvesting 20 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Teresia was only able to harvest 8 bags of maize on 1 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Teresia and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Teresia will educate her children, build a house and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Huruma group will each plant maize plots of between ½ and 1 acre of land.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Terimbere Muhinzi Zone 2 Group

texts.fr:
Désire fait partie du groupe Terimberemuhinzi Zone2. Il a 28 ans et il est marié avec 1 enfant de 6 mois. Son niveau d’éducation est de 4 ans de primaire.

Désire est cultivateur de riz. C’est son premier  cycle de prêt avec ACB. Il va utiliser son crédit afin d’acheter des engrais chimiques pour son agriculture de riz. 

Sa stratégie pour la croissance de son business est de faire la semence sélectionnée.  Dans les prochaines années, Désire voudrait agrandir la surface de la culture du riz en achetant d’autres champs. Avec les profits, il prévoit d’ d’éduquer et soigner son enfant.
texts.en:
Désiré is part of the Terimbere Muhinzi Zone 2 group. He is 28 years old and is married with a 6-month-old child. His level of education is four years of primary school.

Désiré is a rice farmer. This is his first loan cycle with ACB. He will use his credit loan to buy fertilizer for his rice-farming activity.

His strategy for growing his business is to use selected seedlings. In coming years, he would like to extend the area devoted to rice farming by acquiring other fields. With the profits he plans to educate and care for his child.

loans.use: buy fertilizer for his rice-farming activity.

loans.name: Shamim's Group

texts.en:
Shamim's group is comprised of three hard-working women. Shamim is 18 years old and lives in the district of Nateete in the northern region of Kampala, Uganda. For the past two years, Shamim has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells charcoal. 

To help expand her business, Shamim has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more charcoal for resale, and will help Shamim to generate greater profits and buy new clothes for herself. Shamim hopes that in the future she will be able to expand her business. 

Shamim is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training. The ELA program has increased Shamim's future prospects by helping her to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy more charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Teddy

texts.en:
Teddy is 17 years old and lives in the town of Nateete in the Kampala North region of Uganda. Teddy has been working hard to manage her small business, which sells fish at the local market. 

To help expand her business, Teddy has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more fish for resale, and will help Teddy to generate greater profits and pay school fees for herself. Teddy hopes that in the future she will be able to become a doctor. 

Teddy is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training. The ELA program has increased Teddy's future prospects by helping her to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase more fish for resale.

loans.name: Yuuya S.h.g B Group

texts.en:
Eliud is the facilitator of Yuuya group. Eliud and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Eliud takes care of five children at home. He joined One Acre Fund due to One Acre Fund’s best prices and in order to ensure food security for his family and later educate them. In the recent 2011 season, Eliud had a very good maize yield, harvesting 12  bags on ½ an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Eliud was only able to harvest 1.5 bags of maize on ½  acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Eliud and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Eliud will educate his children, build a house and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Yuuya group will each plant maize plots of between ½ and 1 acre of land.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Mary Rose

texts.en:
Mary Rose is from Calamba, Misamis Occidental. She is 21 years old. Mary Rose is married and has two children. 

To make a living, Mary Rose is running a general store, selling a variety of food and home products such as candies, shampoos, and soaps to the local community. Mary Rose has been engaged in her business for over twoyears and earns approximately 2,800 PHP a month.

Mary Rose is requesting a loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand the store's offerings. In 2010, Mary Rose joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand her store's offerings.

loans.name: Modo

texts.en:
Modo is a 28-year-old married woman with five children, all of whom are in school. She has had a business of selling vegetables in Yei, South Sudan for the last four years.

Modo requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase tomatoes and onions to sell. She will use her extra income to pay for her children to go to school.

loans.use: to purchase tomatoes and onions for resale.

loans.name: Angela

texts.en:
Angela is a 38-year-old married lady. She runs a retail shop to earn a living. She has been in this business for four years and has employed one person. Even though she runs her business in a competitive environment, she is able to retain her customers because of her good customer care. Angela thanks Faulu Kenya for training her on good customer care. She also farms for extra income.
Angela hopes to grow her business in five years. She has requested a loan of 30,000 Kenya shillings (KES) to buy sugar, tea leaves, and maize flour.

loans.use: To buy sugar, tea leaves, and maize flour.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase some bags of bread flour in order to make loaves of bread to resell at a profit.

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Apolinario

texts.en:
Apolinario comes from a large family. He was given the opportunity to enter college and took courses in criminology, but it’s sad to say that he only finished two years. He did not continue college because his parents could not afford his expenses in school. Now, Apolinario is 56 years old, and married with four children. He engages in the farming business, planting rice in his village. His wife is a housekeeper.

With his interest to help his children finish their college education, Apolinario did his best just to pay for their college fees. He sold part of his farm just to support the needs of his children in school. Nowadays, Apolinario is proud to share that his four children are all working as seaman and already have their own families.

Apolinario doesn’t want to rely only on his children because they already have their own families. For his farming business, Apolinario is asking for a loan of 50,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) to buy seeds, fertilizers, herbicides, and insecticides to use in farming.

loans.use: To buy seeds, fertilizers, herbicides, and insecticides to use in farming.

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en:
Hellen is 20 years old and lives in the town of Natete in the Kampala North region of Uganda. For the past year, Hellen has been working hard to manage her restaurant, which sells food.

To help expand her business, Hellen has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings (UGX) from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy food for cooking for resale, and will help Hellen to generate greater profits and buy medication for her mother. Hellen hopes that in the future she will be able to expand her business into a big hotel. 

Hellen is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training. The ELA program has increased Hellen's future prospects by helping her to improve her business.

loans.use: To buy food to cook and sell.

loans.name: Dolores

texts.en:
This is Dolores, a 43-year-old resident of Pasay City, Philippines, who is married to Roger, an electrician, and the mother of three children. With assistance from her husband, she manages their household while operating her business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.

Dolores operates an LPG business, purchasing Liquefied Petroleum Gas tanks from wholesalers and then selling each at a small profit. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community, and she earns a minimum of 300 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales everyday.

To help her continue business operations, Dolores is requesting a Php9,000 loan to buy more stocks of LPG tanks to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her income as she expands her business.

Dolores hopes her enterprise will grow more this coming year, and she dreams of being able to give her children a good and high quality education through all of her hard work. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God that she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional stocks of LPG products needed in her business.

loans.name: Monique

texts.en: Monique, who is 24 years old and engaged to be married, sells used clothes in a store she has been running for five years.  She would like a loan to buy more clothes to sell. The profits will be reinvested into her business which she would love to see grow in the future.

loans.use: to buy more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Rehama

texts.en: Rehama, a 30-year-old mother of two children aged 8 and 11, both of whom are in school, is married to a technician. She sells used clothes in a store that she has run for nine years. Rehama would like a loan in order to buy more clothes for her store. The profits will be used for savings and to build a home for her family.

loans.use: to buy more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Claudine

texts.en:
Claudine is 49 years old,  married, and has five children between ages of 14 and 27. She sells potatoes and charcoal, which she has been doing for six years. 

Claudine is requesting a loan, which she will use to buy more potatoes and charcoal to sell. The profits will be used to pay school fees and for saving for her future. Claudine would love to see her business prosper and run her own charcoal store in the future.

loans.use: to purchase more charcoal  and potatoes to sell.

loans.name: Ushindi A Group

texts.en:
Henry is the facilitator of the Ushindi group. Henry and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Henry takes care of six children at home. He joined One Acre Fund due to One Acre Fund’s best prices and in order to ensure food security for his family and later educate them. In the recent 2011 season, Henry had an excellent maize yield, harvesting 6 bags on ½ an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund,  Henry was only able to harvest 2 bags of maize on ½  acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Henry and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Henry will educate his children and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Ushindi A group will each plant maize plots of between ½ and 1 acre of land.

In the photograph above, Henry is pictured with his group members.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Perpetua Wanjiku

texts.en:
Perpetua Wanjiku repaid her first loan and her business has been doing well.  Her monthly income is 15,000 KES.

Perpetua Wanjiku is applying for her second loan term with KADET LTD, which she will use to buy more medicines to add to her shop. With the anticipated profit from the business, she will buy a piece of land.  Perpetua Wanjikur hopes to build rental houses, which will provide for her children's education and help her improve the living standard of her family.

loans.use: to purchase medicines and cosmetics to sell.

loans.name: Perficta

texts.en:
Perficta is 58 years old, married, and has one child.  She lives in Pines Oroquieta City. Perficta  has a nipa hut business and earns approximately 5,000 PHP each month. 

Perficta is requesting a loan for 12,000 PHP, which she will use to purchase bamboo for making nipa huts. Perficta has been a member of PMPC for three years. In the future, she hopes to increase her capital. Perficta is a hard working mother and takes good care of her family. She is thankful that PMPC can help her with her financial problems.

loans.use: to purchase bamboo use for making nipa huts.

loans.name: Runda B Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Runda B Group in Western Kenya! Violet is the facilitator of the Runda B group. This group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Violet takes care of eight children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Violet had very good maize yield, harvesting 8 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Ace Fund, Violet was only able to harvest 0.5 bags of maize on 1 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Violet  and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Violet will educate her children and ensure food security for her family.

In 2012, the members of Runda B group will each plant  between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

In the photograph above, Violet is pictured with her group members.

loans.use: To source farming inputs such as seeds and fertilizer at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Joana

texts.en:
Joana is 28 years old and single.  She lives in Pasay City, Philippines. She manages her household while operating her business so that she can meet her everyday expenses.  

Joana operates a food stall. In the Philippines, the working community and most families eat home-cooked meals during the evenings where all of the family is at home to take part in the meal. This is not only a family tradition but a matter of convenience and frugal living. It is considered a waste of money and time to pay for cooking gas and food for one or two people when buying cooked rice and meat cost less than raw food. 

Joana is also in  direct selling for additional income. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns approximately 500 PHP a day.

Joana is requesting a loan for 15,000 PHP, which will help her continue operations of her business. She will be using the loan to buy more quantities of products such as meats, rice, vegetables, condiments, and seasonings. She expects a boost in her income as she expands her business.  

Joana hopes to finish her degree and find a stable job after finishing college; she also wants to see her business expand. She meets with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and to draw strength and inspiration from God.

All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Docus' Group

texts.en:
Docus's group is comprised of 3 hard-working women. 

Docus is 20 years old and lives in the town of Rukoki in the Fort Portal region of Uganda. She is married and has one child who is currently in school. For the past 4 years, Docus has been working hard to manage her market stall where she sells vegetables. 

To help expand her business, Docus has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more vegetables for resale. It will help Docus to generate greater profits and pay school fees for herself. Docus hopes that in the future she will be able to buy a plot of land. 

Docus is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training. The ELA program has increased Docus's future prospects by giving her the opportunity to learn how to compete with other business people.

loans.use: to buy more vegetables for resale.

loans.name: Nasianda Yhc Group

texts.en:
Agnes is the facilitator of the Nasianda YHC group. Agnes and her group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Agnes takes care of three children at home. She joined One Acre Fund due to One Acre Fund’s best prices and in order to ensure food security for her family and later educate them. In the recent 2011 season, Agnes had an excellent maize yield, harvesting 10 bags on ½ an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund,  Agnes was only able to harvest 4 bags of maize on ½  acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Agnes and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Agnes will educate her children and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Nasianda YHC group will each plant maize plots between ½ and 1 acre of land.

The photograph shows the Facilitator,  Agnes, and her group; the field officer appears on the far left. The total number of members should be seven but one is absent.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase some clothing items for resale.

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Lily

texts.en:
Lily is 38, married, and blessed with one child. Her husband is a tricycle driver, which transports passengers. Her husband's daily earnings are used for their daily expenditures. Lily and her husband have planted rice in the Philippines for four years. She earns an income of approximately PHP 50,000 from her her two hectare farm. Her earnings are invested back into the farmland in order to have additional areas to plant.
 
Lily has gone abroad and worked as a domestic helper for four years. She works abroad because of their financial difficulties. She comes back to the Philippines when she has enough earnings that can serve as her capital for her farming business. Still, her earnings are not enough. Therefore, Lily is asking for a loan of PHP 50,000 to purchase seeds, fertilizers, insecticides, and pay for labor. She is looking forward to having a successful farming business.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers, insecticides and pay for labor

loans.name: Mary Jaen

texts.en:
Mary Jaen is from Baliangao, Misamis Occidental. She is 20 years old. Mary Jaen is married and has one child. 

To make a living, Mary Jaen owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of products such as toothpaste, shampoo, and many other products to the local community. Mary Jaen has been engaged in her business for over one year and earns approximately 2,800 PHP a month for these activities. 

Mary Jaen is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. In 2010, Mary Jaen joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and working capital

loans.name: Stevenia's Group

texts.en:
Stevenia's group is comprised of three hard-working women. Stevenia is 22 years old and lives in the town of Rukoki in the Fort Portal region of Uganda. She is married and has three children, with one of them currently in school. For the past year, Stevenia has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells sugar and soap. 

To help expand her business, Stevenia has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy sugar and soap for resale, and will help Stevenia to generate greater profits and pay school fees and medical expenses. Stevenia hopes that in the future she will be able to buy a plot of land and build a house. 

Stevenia is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training. The ELA program has increased Stevenia's future prospects by helping her to learn life planning skills like how to be assertive.

loans.use: to buy sugar and soap for resale

loans.name: Sofia

texts.en:
Sofia is 17 years old and lives in the town of Rukoki in the Fort Portal region of Uganda. She is single and has one child. For the past three years, Sofia has been working hard to manage her hotel, which sells food. 

To help expand her business, Sofia has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy food for cooking for resale and will help Sofia to generate greater profits and buy food to feed her family. Sofia hopes that in the future she will be able to buy a plot of land and build a house. 

Sofia is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training. The ELA program has increased Sofia's future prospects by helping to teach her job skills like hair dressing.

loans.use: to buy food for cooking to sell

loans.name: Angie

texts.en:
Angie is 30 years old and lives in Canubay, Oroquieta City. She is  a single mother with two children. 
Angie has a vegetable vending business and earns approximately PHP 4,000 each month doing this type of work. She has requested a loan of PHP 3,000 to purchase fertilizer to grow vegetables. Angie has been a member of PMPC for a month.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer to grow vegetables

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel is a resident of Murang'a in Central Kenya and has been in farming for 20 years, producing milk and tea and selling to the local market. He is married with four adult children with the last two enrolled in post-secondary education.

Daniel has requested a loan of 63,600 KES from Juhudi Kilimo for purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says the additional dairy cow will improve his family's livelihood. This is his first loan request with Juhudi Kilimo and he promises to pay in order to get more.

He is happy Juhudi Kilimo is a good partner and farmers stand to gain more.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Eddy

texts.en:
Eddy is 20 years old and lives in the town of Rukoki in the Fort Portal region of Uganda. She is married and has one child. For the past six years, Eddy has been working hard to manage her market, which sells fruit. 

To help expand her business, Eddy has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more fruit for resale, and will help Eddy to generate greater profits and for medical expenses. Eddy hopes that in the future she will be able to buy a plot of land. 

Eddy is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to micro-finance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training. The ELA program has increased Eddy's future prospects by helping her to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy more fruit for resale.

loans.name: Ubumwe Group

texts.fr:
Jason fait partie du groupe Ubumwe. Le nom du groupe signifie «unité ». Il a 36 ans et il est marié avec 5 enfants de 4 à 15 ans, Dont 3 scolarisés. Son niveau d’éducation est de 7 ans de primaire.

Jason est cultivateur de riz. C’est son deuxième  cycle de prêt avec ACB. Il va utiliser son crédit afin d’acheter des engrais chimiques pour son agriculture de riz. 

Sa stratégie pour la croissance de son business est de faire la semence sélectionnée du riz.  Dans les prochaines années, Jason voudrait agrandir la surface de riz en achetant d’autres champs. Avec les profits, Jason prévoit d’éduquer et soigner ses enfants.
texts.en:
Jason is part of the group called Ubumwe, which means "unity". He is 36 years old and married, with 5 children between the ages of 4 and 15. 3 of his children are in school. He completed 7 years of primary school. 

Jason is a rice farmer. This is his second loan cycle with ACB. He is going to use his loan to buy fertilizer for his rice cultivation. 

His strategy for the growth of his business is to use pedigreed rice seeds. In the next few years, Jason would like to buy more fields in order to expand the surface area of his rice fields. With the profits, Jason plans to educate and care for his children.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer for rice fields.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is 56 years old, a retired teacher,  widowed with three children who are adults. Jane practices rabbit keeping in the area of Mwiki, Nairobi where there is good flow of customers. She has been in this business for the last three years and gets an income of KES 10,000 per month.

She is applying for her first loan of KES 30,000 from KADET LTD which she plans to use to buy rabbit pellets and building materials for rental houses. She will use the anticipated profit to construct the rental houses.

Jane hopes to have her own rental houses and also improve her rabbit keeping and keep birds that produce eggs for sale. She is very hardworking and focused.

loans.use: To buy rabbit pellets and start constructing a rental house.

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam is 21 years old and lives in the town of Rukoki in the Fort Portal region of Uganda. She is married and has two children with one of them currently in school. For the past three years, Mariam has been working hard to manage her salon, where she does hairdressing for local women. 

To help expand her business, Mariam has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase the equipment needed to do special braids, and it will help Mariam to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her children. Mariam hopes that in the future she will be able to educate her children. 

Mariam is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to micro-finance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training. The ELA program has increased Mariam's future prospects by helping her to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase the equipment needed to do special braids.

loans.name: Ma.teresa

texts.en:
Ma. Teresa is married to a driver and has three school-aged children. She is 44 years old. To better support her family, she plants and harvests corn to sell in the village of Sta. Maria, province of Isabela. She has been in this field for 21 years and earns about P30,000 per crop season.

At this time, she is requesting a loan of P30,000 to buy farm input such as fertilizers and corn seedlings to supplement her farm. She hopes to harvest more corn, which will enable her to generate a large income to better feed her family and improve her business.

loans.use: to buy farm inputs such as fertilizers and corn seedlings to supplement her farm.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizer.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy seedlings and farm manure for her farm.

loans.name: Elijah Wahura

texts.en:
Elijah used the previous loan amount to buy another quarry. He has seen his business grow and it is very profitable. He repaid the loan amount well and in good time.

This will be his third loan. He plans to use the loan amount to buy another quarry.

In the future, Elijah hopes to own a large portion of land for his quarry business.

loans.use: to buy another quarry site.

loans.name: Merveille Plus Group

texts.en:
Dieu Donné is the chairman of a community bank named “Merveille Plus”, which is composed of 15 micro entrepreneurs. They are united in solidarity to receive loans from Kiva through IMF HOPE RDC, with the goal of developing their businesses.

Dieu Donné started his business in 1991, selling miscellaneous goods. Today he operates a general boutique. He is 39 years old, married, and has a seven-year-old son who attends school. Dieu Donné is happy to be part of one of Hope’s groups that he joined in 2010. His business has been reinforced through the seven different loans he received, and then repaid them correctly. His store generates a profit of about $110 each week.
 
He intends to use the next loan to increase the inventory of his business by buying items for resale in the store.  In order to increase the profit and diversify his business, he will add beverages. His dream is to someday open a soft drink store. 

Dieu Donné sells in the north eastern area of Kinshasa.

loans.use: to purchase the store's items for resale in order to increase the profit.

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is 25 years old and the mother of a three-year-old child.  She runs a boutique to earn a living.  She has been in the business for three years.  She also owns rental houses, which earn her extra income.
 
Since she joined Faulu Kenya, she has learned how to run her business well because she has been trained in business management skills.  She hopes to expand her business into wholesale in the future.

She needs a loan of 20,000 Kenya shillings to buy shoes and clothes.

loans.use: to buy shoes and clothes.

loans.name: Nevless' Group

texts.en:
Nevless' group is composed of six hard-working women. Nevless is 21 years old and lives in the town of Rukoki in the Fort Portal region of Uganda. She is married and has three children, who are all currently in school. For the past three years, Nevless has been working hard to manage her wholesale shop, which sells beans and maize. 

To help expand her business, Nevless has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more beans and maize for resale, and will help Nevless to generate greater profits and pay for school fees herself. Nevless hopes that in the future, she will be able to buy a motorcycle. 

Nevless is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training. The ELA program has increased Nevless' future prospects by helping to teach her job skills like hair dressing and how to save.

loans.use: to buy more beans and maize for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy maize meal, sugar, and cooking oil to add to her shop.

loans.name: Castro

texts.pt:
Nasceu na cidade de Matola, Província de Maputo, sul  de Moçambique, casado e pai de 2 filhos todos frenquentam a Escola. Fez a 5ª classe e não continuou por falta de condições financeiras pela parte dos pais.  Vive na casa propria com a sua familia e sustenta a sua mãe enviando dinheiro para auxiliar nas dispesas alimentares. 

É motorista ha mais de 6 anos e tem um salario de 9.000.00mt por mês que aplica nas despesas de casa e poupa algum na sua conta bancaria.
Nunca teve emprestimos noutros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku atravez de uma amiga que tambem é cliente desta instituição. Este é o seu quinto emprestimo na Hluvuku no valor de 21.000.00mt,com qual pretende comprar material de construção para a obra da sua casa(areia, cimento, pedra, ferro, e outros). Os primeiros emprestimos foram de: 6.000.00mt, 6.000.00mt, 10.000.00mt, e 10.300.00mt,  para habitação.
Compromete se a pagar devidamente e no futuro pretende construir uma oficina , para tal tenciona solicitar mais emprestimos a Hluvuku.
texts.en:
Castro was born in the city of Matola, in the province of Maputo in southern Mozambique. He is married and the father of two children, who are both still in school. He went to school through fifth grade but had to drop out because of his parents' financial difficulties. He lives in his own home with his family and also supports his mother financially, sending her money to help with her food expenses 

He's been a driver for more than six years and earns a salary of 9,000 meticals a month. He uses his earnings to pay for household expenses and also saves a little in a bank account.
He's never had loans from other banks. He learned about Hluvuku from a friend who is also a client of the institution. This is his fifth loan with Hluvuku, in the amount of 21,000 meticals, which he will use to purchase construction materials (sand, cement, stone, iron, etc.) to build his house. His first loans, in the amounts of 6,000, 6,000, 10,000, and 10,300 meticals, were all also used for his home.
He is committed to paying off this loan without any problems and in the future intends to ask for further loans from Hluvuku to build an office.

loans.use: to purchase construction materials (sand, cement, stone, iron, etc.) to build his house.

loans.name: Namanjala B Group

texts.en:
Oscar is the facilitator of the Namanjala B group. Oscar and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. Oscar takes care of eight children at home. He joined One Acre Fund for One Acre Fund’s best prices and to ensure food security for his family and later educate them. In the recent 2011 season, Oscar had an excellent maize yield harvesting 11 bags on ½ acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Oscar was only able to harvest three bags of maize on ½ acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Oscar and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from his maize sales, Oscar will educate his children and invest in raising livestock.

In 2012, the members of Namanjala B group will each plant maize plots between ½ and 1 acre of land.

In the photograph above, Oscar is pictured with his group members.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season

loans.name: Simon

texts.en:
Simon is 24 years old and single.  He does motorbike transport to earn a living.  He has been in this business for two years.  

Through Faulu Kenya, he has been inspired to work hard in his business.  He has also been trained in business management skills.  He hopes to expand his business and employ people.

Simon has requested a loan of 40,000 Kenya shillings to buy a motorbike.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike.

loans.name: Fonseca

texts.pt:
Nasceu na Província de Nampula, norte de Moçambique, casado e pai de 1 filho que ainda frenquenta a Escola. Fez a 12ª classe e não continuou porque foi encorporado no serviço militar. Vive na casa propria com a sua familia e sustenta a seu irmão enviando dinheiro para auxiliar nas dispesas alimentares. 

Saiu de Nampula para Maputo em missão de serviço, é militar ha mais de 24 anos e negociante ha mais de 9 anos dedica-se a venda de produtos de primeira nessecidade e tem um rendimento somando ao salario de 13.890.00mt por mês que aplica nas despesas de casa e poupa algum na sua conta bancaria.
Nunca teve emprestimos noutros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku atravez de uma amiga que tambem é cliente desta instituição. Este é o seu quarto emprestimo na Hluvuku no valor de 20.000.00mt,com qual pretende comprar produtos(arroz, amendoim, farinha, oleo, e outros). Os primeiros emprestimos foram de: 15.000.00mt, 18.000.00mt, e 20.000.00mt,  para o negocio.
Compromete se a pagar devidamente e no futuro pretende fazer crescer o seu negocio , para tal tenciona solicitar mais emprestimos a Hluvuku.
texts.en:
Fonseca was born in the province of Nampula in northern Mozambique. He is married and has a son who is still in school. He went to school through the twelfth grade but dropped out because he joined the military. He lives in his own home with his family and also supports his brother financially, sending him money to help with his food expenses.

He left Nampula for Maputo to complete his military service and has been a soldier more than 24 years. He has been a businessman for more than 9 years, selling staple goods. He earns a total of 13,890 meticals a month. He uses the money to cover household expenses and is able to save some in his bank account.
He's never had loans from other banks. He learned about Hluvuku from a friend who is also a client of the institution. This is his fourth loan with Hluvuku, in the amount of 20,000 meticals, which he will use to buy products (rice, peanuts, flour, oil, etc.) for his business. His other loans were in the amounts of 15,000, 18,000, and 20,000 meticals, which he also invested in the business.
He is committed to paying off this loan without any problems and in the future intends to ask for further loans from Hluvuku to expand his business.

loans.use: to buy products (rice, peanuts, flour, oil, etc.) for his business.

loans.name: Jessica's Group

texts.en:
Jessica's group comprises two hardworking women. Jessica is 22 years old and lives in the town of Rukoki in the Fort portal region of Uganda. She is married and has three children, two of whom are currently in school. For the past three years, Jessica has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells soft drinks.

To help expand her business, Jessica has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings (UGX) from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more fruits to make juice for resale, and will help Jessica to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her children. Jessica hopes that in the future she will be able to build a house of her own.

Jessica is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training. The ELA program has increased Jessica's future prospects by helping her to improve her business.

loans.use: To buy more fruits to make juice for resale.

loans.name: Maribel

texts.en:
Maribel is a married woman having three children. Maribel is 32 years old, residing at Calamba, Misamis Occidental: Philippines. 

Maribel owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products including soft drinks, soaps, and many other items to earn a living and she's been in this business for four years. Each month, she earns 3,600 Philippines pesos (PHP) doing this type of business. 

She requested a loan of 4,000 PHP to purchase products to resell. Maribel has been a member of GDMPC for a year. In the future, Maribel wants to expand/improve her business and to finish the education of her children.

loans.use: To purchase products to resell.

loans.name: Mohamed

texts.en:
Mohamed is married and has two children. He lives in the Coastal town of Changamwe, Kenya. He is a poultry farmer, a trade he has done for the last two years. He is also a dairy farmer.

He is applying for a loan of 50,000 KES to buy more chicks and chicken marsh, and building materials to expand the rearing space. He has set his goals at acquiring more space to breed more chickens, and from this income he will be able to purchase a pickup to assist in distribution and meet the basic needs of his family.

loans.use: To purchase chicks, chicken feed, and building materials.

loans.name: Boniface

texts.en:
Boniface is age 33 and married with 2 children ages 7 and 2 years. He has been farming for the last 10 years in his hometown of Murang'a in Central Kenya. His farm currently produces coffee, tomatoes, and vegetables for the local market.

Boniface has requested for a loan of 30,000 Kenya shillings (KES) from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase poultry birds for a new farming venture in poultry. He says his poultry proceeds will will help him educate his children. He says his focus is to do heavy commercial farming and rely on farming for all his family needs.

Boniface laments the high cost of animal feeds and rampant diseases. He adds that Juhudi loans is a real relief to farmers.

loans.use: To purchase poultry birds.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice is 38 years old and married to her husband Alexander. They are blessed with three children, all of whom are school-going. Beatrice is a pharmacist in Kajiando market, where most of her clients are both male and female. She has been in this business for the last four years and gets an income of 4,000 Kenya shillings (KES) per month.

Beatrice was introduced to KADET LTD by a KADET staff member. She has good credit history in KADET and she is applying for her second loan of KES 40,000 from KADET LTD. She plans to use KES 20,000 to purchase medicine and KES 20,000 to purchase lab equipment.

She will use the extra profit to start a nursing home. Beatrice hopes to become a wholeseller. She is enterprising and focused.

loans.use: To purchase medicine and lab equipment.

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en: Rebecca used her previous loan of 15,000 Kenya shillings to buy soap, biscuits and sweets. With additional inventory, her business improved.  She hopes to open other outlets of her business in other regions. She has requested for a loan of 60,000 Kenya shillings to buy cooking fat, maize flour and sugar.

loans.use: to buy cooking fat, maize flour and sugar.

loans.name: Martha

texts.en:
Martha is 46 years old, married, and an enterprising businesswoman. She and her husband are blessed with three children, ages 21, 19 and 15, respectively. Martha has been running a retail shop for the past 21 years with the monthly income KES 34,750, which she uses to support her family.

She is applying for her second loan term with KADET LTD after repaying the previous loan successfully. Martha will use the loan to buy a stock of sugar and maize meal to add to her shop. 

With the anticipated profits from the business, she will educate her children. Her hopes and dreams are to open a wholesale shop.

loans.use: to buy a stock of sugar and maize meal to add to her shop.

loans.name: Duterimbere Mubuhinzi Group

texts.fr:
Séraphine fait partie du groupe Duterimbere Mu Buhinzi. Le nom du groupe signifie «développement de cultivateur». Elle a 57 ans et elle est mariée avec 5 enfants de 4 à 15 ans, elle a 1 personne en charge autre que ses enfants. Dont 3 scolarisés. Son niveau d’éducation est de 3  ans de primaire.

Séraphine est cultivatrice de riz. C’est son premier  cycle de prêt avec ACB. Elle va utiliser son crédit afin d’acheter des engrais chimiques pour son agriculture de riz. 

Sa stratégie pour la croissance de son business est de faire la semence sélectionnée du riz.  Dans les prochaines années, Séraphine voudrait agrandir la surface de la culture de riz en achetant d’autres champs. Avec les profits, Séraphine prévoit d’éduquer et soigner ses enfants.
texts.en:
Séraphine belongs to the “Duterimbere Mu Buhinzi” group. The group’s name means “Promoting farming.” She is 57 years old and married, with five children ranging from four to 15 years of age. She has one additional dependent apart from her children, three of whom are in school. Her educational level is three years of primary school.

Séraphine  is a rice farmer. This is her first loan cycle with ACB. She is going to use her loan in order to buy chemical fertilizers for her agricultural work. Her business strategy is to use selected seeds. In the years to come, Séraphine would like to expand her cultivated land by purchasing additional plots for growing rice. Séraphine plans to use her earnings to support her children and provide for their education.

loans.use: to buy chemical fertilizers for growing rice

loans.name: Mulango Shg Group

texts.en:
Janet is the facilitator of the Mulango SHG group.  Janet and her group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Janet takes care of five children at home. She joined One Acre Fund for One Acre Fund’s best prices and in order to ensure food security for her family and later educate them. In the recent 2011 season, Janet had an excellent maize yield harvesting 12 ½ bags on ½ acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Janet was only able to harvest four bags of maize on ½  acres of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Janet and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from her maize sales, Janet will educate her children, build a house and invest in raising livestock.

In 2012, the members of Mulango SHG group will each plant maize plots between ½ and 1 acre of land.

In the photograph above, Janet is pictured with her group members and the field officer appears at the far left of the photograph. One member is absent.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season

loans.name: Venancio

texts.en:
Venancio is 62, married and has seven adult children. He is a farmer who raised his family in a village. For almost 44 years, he has owned and managed a rice-farming and hog-raising business; he earns an income of approximately PHP 12,000 per month. Most of his income goes toward their daily consumption and the allowances of his grandchildren. Despite the hardships of life, he has aimed to improve his business because he wants to give his children a better life. Through his patience and hard work, most of his children have finished their studies and they are now professionals. Despite this, he wants to continue managing the business because he wants to earn and save for their future.

He is asking for a loan of PHP 40,000 to buy feed, vitamins and vaccines for his hog-raising business. He mentioned that the loan will help him to make an improvement in his piggery and increase the number of his pigs. He believes that "if there is patience, there is progress." This is his principle in life.

loans.use: to buy feed, vitamins and vaccines for his hog-raising business.

loans.name: Bayraa

texts.en:
Bayraa is 41 and lives with her husband and three kids in a ger (Mongolian yurt) in the Uvurhangai province of Mongolia. Her husband helps with her business. Her eldest daughter is a college student and the other two children are school students. She started her meat retailing business in 2003 by renting a counter in a market. Now she is a trusted supplier of many small restaurants and cafés. Her workplace seemed clean and well-organized for a meat retailer. 

Now that winter is approaching, meat prices will increase; therefore, she wants to save some supplies before that. She is a sharp and diligent women who says, "Now that my daughter joined a college, she needs my support more than anything right now. I will do everything I can to support my daughter." She is requesting 1,000,000 MNT to purchase more meat.

loans.use: to purchase more meat.

loans.name: Nuage Plus Group

texts.en:
Kasav is the leader of a community bank named “Nuage Plus”, which is composed of 15 micro-entrepreneurs united in solidarity to receive loans from Kiva through IMF HOPE RDC, with the goal of developing their businesses.
 
Kasav sells secondhand clothing. She has been in business since 1993. She likes her business and it has prospered thanks to good management and accumulated profits. She is a loyal client of IMF HOPE RDC, and has already received five different loans, repaying them correctly. She intends with the next loan to increase the inventory of her business by purchasing a bundle of secondhand clothing to resell, in order to reinforce the working capital. Currently, she earns a profit of $20 every week. Kasav is 44 years old, married and the mother of two children, ages 2 and 7 years old. One goes to school. 

Kasav's dream is to become a used clothing wholesaler in her area.

loans.use: to purchase a bundle of secondhand clothing to resell at a profit.

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Paul

texts.en:
Paul has practiced farming in Naivasha town for the past three years. He is 33 years old, and married to Everlyne.  

He was introduced to KADET LTD by one of our existing clients and this will be his first loan. He plans to use the loan amount to plant wheat and potatoes.

In the future, Paul hopes to become one of the leading wheat farmers in Naivasha area.

loans.use: to plant wheat and potatoes.

loans.name: Everline

texts.en:
Everline is a 38-year-old businesswoman. To earn a living, she runs a boutique. She has retained her business because of her hard work and determination. Since she joined Faulu Kenya, she has become financially stable because she has used her previous loans to boost her business.

Her desire is to expand her business in five years and grow her clientele. She needs 40,000 Kenyan shillings to buy clothes, handbags and shoes.

loans.use: to buy clothes, handbags and shoes.

loans.name: Massan

texts.fr:
Massan est une femme âgée de 46 ans. Elle est mariée à un Directeur d’école avec qui elle eut 2 enfants. Massan travaille comme revendeuse depuis 2007. Elle achète et revend des produits cosmétiques genre laits et lotions corporels, des parfums …à toutes personnes à son domicile ou comme ambulante à Lomé. Elle achète ces produits au grand marché de Lomé.
Massan a requis son troisième crédit de WAGES afin d’acheter des produits cosmétiques destinés à la vente. Dans les prochaines années, Massan voudrait agrandir sa marchandise. Elle dit qu’avec les profits, Elle prévoit contribuer aux besoins de la famille.
texts.en:
Massan is a 45-year old woman, who is married to a headteacher and has two children. She has worked as a retailer since 2007, buying and selling cosmetics such as body milks and lotions, perfumes...to all sorts of people either from home or on a door-to-door basis in Lomé. She buys these products at Lomé's Grand Market. 

Massan has requested a third loan from WAGES so that she can buy cosmetics for resale. In coming years, she would like to build up her stock. She says that she plans to use the profits she makes to contribute to her family's needs.

loans.use: to buy cosmetics

loans.name: Umoja Farm Group

texts.en:
Ezekiel is the facilitator of the Umoja Farm group. Ezekiel and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Ezekiel takes care of five children at home. He joined One Acre Fund to grow enough to feed his family and to afford farm inputs. In the recent 2011 season, Ezekiel had a very good maize yield harvesting 18 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Ezekiel was only able to harvest six bags of maize on one acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Ezekiel and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from his maize sales, Ezekiel will educate his children and invest in raising livestock.

In 2012, the members of Umoja Farm group will each plant maize plots between ½ and 1 acre of land.

In the photograph above, Ezekiel is pictured with his group members.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice is 61 years old married to Lepapa, and they are blessed with four children. She runs a school in the area of Olekaitioriori, Kajiando, and most of her children come from the locality. She has been in this business for the past two years and earns an income of KES 10,000 per month.


Alice was introduced to KADET LTD by a KADET staff member. She has good credit history in KADET and she is applying for her second loan of KES  50,000 from KADET LTD. She plans to use KES 30,000 to construct a classroom and KES 20,000 to purchase desks. She will use the extra profits to start a secondary school.

Alice hopes to start a high school and even a college. She is very visionary and hardworking.

loans.use: to construct a classroom and purchase desks.

loans.name: Bellarina

texts.en:
Bellarina is 34 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with two children.
 
Bellarina has a shop, where she sells canned goods, snacks and beverages. She has had this business for four years. She requested a loan for PHP 9,000 to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages.

Bellarina has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. In the future, Bellarina hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages for resale.

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
Stephen is 42 years old, married and has five children. He distributes water so as to earn a living for his family. He has nine years of experience in the business and has employed one person. He also does farming to supplement his income. Previously, he was employed in a hotel.

Stephen desires to open other outlets of his business in other regions in five years. He needs 100,000 Kenya shillings to buy water tanks and pipes.

loans.use: to buy a water tank and pipes.

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en:
Lorna is from Calamba, Misamis Occidental. She is 47 years old. Lorna is married and has two children. 

To make a living, Lorna owns a general store, selling a variety of food and home used products in the local community, such as candies, cigarettes, shampoo, soaps and many other items. Lorna has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 3,600 PHP a month for these activities.

Lorna is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. In 2010, Lorna joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to to save as a reserve for future emergencies				.

loans.use: to purchase new items in order to expand her product offering.

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn is 34 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with three children.
 
Jocelyn has a poultry farm that sells ducks and also duck eggs or balot. She has had this business for eight years. She requested a loan for PHP 10,000 to buy animal feed for the ducks.

Jocelyn has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. In the future, Jocelyn hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy animal feed for the ducks.

loans.name: Ayoko

texts.fr:
Ayoko est une femme âgée de 31 ans. Elle est célibataire. 
Ayoko travaille comme revendeuse depuis 2011. Elle achète et revend du sel de cuisine en gros à toutes personnes dans une boutique. Elle s’approvisionne du sel au Ghana et travaille seule. 
Ayoko a requis son premier crédit de WAGES afin d’acheter de la grande quantité de sel de cuisine destiné à la vente. Elle pense réinvestir ses profits supplémentaires dans le développement de son commerce.
Dans les prochaines années, Ayoko voudrait agrandir son activité. Elle dit qu’avec les profits, Elle prévoit s’assurer une vie heureuse.
texts.en:
Ayoko is a 31-year-old woman. She is single. 

Ayoko has worked as a retailer since 2011. She buys and resells cooking salt in bulk to everyone in a store. She stocks up on salt in Ghana and works alone. 

Ayoko requested her first loan from WAGES in order to purchase the large quantity of cooking salt she intends to sell. She plans on reinvesting her extra profits in the development of her business. 

In the next few years, Ayoko would like to expand her business. She says that she will be able to provide a happy life for herself with her profits.

loans.use: to buy sacks of cooking salt.

loans.name: Ruth

texts.fr:
Ruth  est née au Rwanda et a 39 ans. Elle est mariée avec 6 enfants de 7 à 17 ans, dont 6 scolarisés. Elle a une autre personne en charge autre que ses enfants. Son niveau d’éducation est 4 ans de secondaire. 

Ruth est salariée mais aussi elle fait l'activite de transport avec le taxi minibus. C’est son premier cycle de prêt avec ACB. Elle va utiliser son crédit afin d’acheter 1 pare-brise d’une véhicule taxi mini bus, 1 boitier de direction pour faire l'entretien de son taxi minibus.

Sa stratégie pour la croissance de son business est de travailler beaucoup pour acheter un autre véhicule.
Ruth voudrait être une grande commerçante. Avec le profit  Ruth voudrait  scolariser et soigner ses enfants.
texts.en:
Ruth was born in Rwanda. She is 39 years old and married with six children aged 7 to 17, all in school. She also looks after another dependent person in addition to her own children. She attended four years of high school. 

Ruth is a salaried worker but she also works in transport with has a minibus taxi. This is her first loan cycle with ACB. She will use the credit to buy a windshield for a mini bus taxi vehicle and a steering box.

Her business growth strategy is to work hard in order to buy another vehicle. She would like to become a great businesswoman. Ruth will use the profits to ensure her children’s education and healthcare.

loans.use: to buy a windshield for a mini bus taxi vehicle and a steering box

loans.name: Goren

texts.en:
Goren is 33 years old and lives in the Philippines. He is married with four children.
 
Goren is providing motorcycle transportation, or habal-habal, services. He has had this business for ten years. He requested a loan for PHP 10,000 to buy tools and to pay for the gasoline for maintenance.

Goren has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. In the future, Goren hopes to improve his business.

loans.use: to buy tools and pay for the gasoline for maintenance.

loans.name: Resurection Plus Group

texts.en:
Bonheur, 38 and single, is the leader of the Community Bank named “Resurection Plus”, which is composed of 11 members united in solidarity to receive loans from Kiva through the MFI HOPE RDC with the goal of developing their businesses. 

Bonheur has been in the business world since 1999. He operates a general store in the western part of Kinshasa. He is a loyal client of the MFI HOPE RDC, having already received ten different loans and repaid them properly. He intends to use the next loan to increase the inventory of his goods by buying sacks of sugar, milk, rice, etc. to resell with the aim of increasing his profits. Each day, Bonheur's business brings in a profit of $40. His ambition is to build a facility to store goods in his area. He is happy and will continue getting loans from Kiva through MFI HOPE DRC in order to develop his business.

loans.use: to increase his inventory by purchasing sugar, milk, sardines, etc. for resale.

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Mbanacho Group

texts.en:
Fred is the facilitator of the Mbanacho group. Fred and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Fred takes care of four children at home. He joined One Acre Fund for One Acre Fund’s best prices and to access fertilizers and hybrid seed. In the recent 2011 season, Fred had a very good maize yield harvesting 12 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Fred was only able to harvest 2.5 bags of maize on one acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Fred and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from his maize sales, Fred will educate his children and invest in raising livestock
.
In 2012, the members of Mbanacho group will each plant maize plots between ½ and 1 acre of land.

In the photograph above, Fred is pictured with his group members.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Fridah

texts.en: Fridah runs a grocery store, selling soft drinks and charcoal. She has always divided her time well to manage her businesses and has employed one person to assist her in her tasks. Fridah previously requested a loan of 30,000 KES which she used to buy vegetables. Since she serviced the loan, her grocery business improved, thus generating more income. Fridah needs a loan of 100,000 KES to buy soft drinks and charcoal.

loans.use: To buy soft drinks and charcoal

loans.name: Leonidez

texts.en:
Leonidez is from Bunawan, Calamba, Misamis Occidental. She is 49 years old, married and has 5 adult-aged children. Leonidez has owned and operated a business selling goods in the local community for over 2 years, earning approximately 2,800 PHP a month.

Leonidez is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used  to purchase additional product goods such as shampoo, sardines and etc. 

In 2010, Leonidez joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to buy a transport vehicle used in the business.

loans.use: to purchase additional product goods such as shampoo, sardines and etc

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy tools and gasoline

loans.name: Roda

texts.en: Roda is 25 years old and married, with two children. both in school. She has operated a business selling charcoal in Yei, South Sudan for four years. Roda has requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase charcoal. She will use her extra income from this loan to pay for her children to go to school.

loans.use: to purchase charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Norovsuren

texts.en:
Thirty-year-old Norovsuren lives with her daughter and disabled brother in Uvurhangai Province, Mongolia. Having started her garment-retailing by selling socks in the streets in 1999, she now owns two counters in the province's biggest market.

Well-known and well-experienced, Norovsuren is a sharp and hardworking woman who says, "I started my business from scratch. I worked hard to go this far." Now that winter is approaching, she needs warmer clothes to sell and is requesting 2,500,000 to buy more garments.

loans.use: to buy more garments.

loans.name: Perlita

texts.en:
Perlita, a responsible housewife who manages a hog-raising business to supplement her husband's income, is 56 years old and has five adult children. Being responsible parents, they have helped each other over the years to earn income to support the needs of their family, placing special emphasis on the education of their children. As a result of their patience and hard work, most of their children have earned degrees and found good jobs.

In order to save for future emergencies and to help finance the education of her grandchildren, Perlita aims to improve her business. She is therefore requesting a loan of P25,000 to buy feeds, vitamins and additional piglets to raise.

loans.use: to buy feeds, vitamins and additional piglets to raise.

loans.name: Lenie

texts.en:
Lenie is 26 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with three children.
 
Lenie has a shop where she sells canned goods, snacks & beverages. She has had this business for five years. She requested a loan for PHP 10,000 to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages.

Lenie has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. In the future, Lenie hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages

loans.name: Suuranbubu's Group

texts.en:
Suuranbubu is the leader of this group. She is 50 years old and together with her husband who is a farmer, she has raised three children. Suuranbubu works in a factory in order to earn money to meet the daily needs. The family cultivates agricultural products. They started this activity eight years ago with an initial investment of 5,000 soms. At the moment, Suuranbubu needs money for processing the land. For this purpose, she applied for the loan. With money received from the loan, she will buy mineral fertilizers. In the future, with the profits gained from selling the harvest, she wishes to save money to purchase a vehicle.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase mineral fertilizers

loans.name: Kennedy

texts.en:
Kennedy is a 42-year-old married man with four children. He runs a grocery, mainly selling sweet potatoes, bananas, sugarcane and vegetables. Kennedy has been in business for over ten years. He also farms, growing tea and rearing cattle to generate more income for his family. Kennedy is known in his local community as a hardworking man and this has helped him to build a good reputation with his customers.

Kennedy wants to expand his business into wholesale in five years. He needs a loan of 100,000 KES to buy bananas, vegetables and sugarcane.

loans.use: To buy bananas, vegetables and sugarcane

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy clothing stock to sell

loans.name: Moïse Plus Group

texts.en:
“Moïse Plus” is a Community Bank made up of 23 micro entrepreneurs whose chairman is Emmanuel. These members are united and have the same goal to grow their businesses by loans received from Kiva through HOPE RDC. 
Emmanuel sells sacks of charcoal in his area located in the north eastern suburban part of Kinshasa. He began his business in 2004. After hard work and good management, he succeeded in making it thrive thanks to the accumulated profits. He is a loyal client of HOPE RDC who has already received two different loans and has repaid them properly. He intends to reinforce the working capital with the next loan by buying ten charcoal sacks to resell at a profit as people do not have power and hot plates in this area. The business gives him a profit of US$30 every week. Emmanuel is 32 years old, married and the father of four children whose ages vary between 1 and 9 years old. Two of them attend school. His ambition is to change his business by opening a general store.

loans.use: to purchase 10 charcoal sacks  to resell at a profit.

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Bayarmagnai

texts.en:
Bayarmagnai is 33 years old and lives with his wife and two children in a ger (a Mongolian yurt) in Arhangai province, Mongolia. His wife is a nurse, his elder daughter is a student and his younger one goes to kindergarten.

Bayarmagnai started his transportation business in 2001 with his own van. Since he is very experienced and his van is very convenient, he has many regular customers. Bayarmagnai is requesting a loan of 3,000,000 MNT to service his van since it is having some technical problems. Bayarmagnai is a sharp and hardworking man who says, "I do everything I can to make my customers comfortable."

loans.use: To service his van

loans.name: Dina

texts.en: Dina is 40 years old and married, with four children, all in school. She has operated a medical clinic in Yei, South Sudan for nine years. Dina has requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase drugs and gloves. She will use her extra income from this loan to build a permanent house in the future.

loans.use: to purchase drugs and gloves

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy tools and gasoline for maintenance of her jeepney service

loans.name: Simana C Group

texts.en:
Margaret is the facilitator of the Simana C group. Margaret and her group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Margaret takes care of four children at home. She joined One Acre Fund to grow enough to ensure food security for her family and to have additional maize profits to educate her children. In the recent 2011 season, Margaret had a good maize yield harvesting seven bags on ½ acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Margaret was only able to harvest one bag of maize on ½ acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Margaret and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from her maize sales, Margaret will educate her children and invest in raising livestock.

In 2012, the members of Simana C group will each plant maize plots between ½ and 1 acre of land.

Margaret is pictured with her group members in the photograph.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Yawoa

texts.fr:
Yawoa est une femme âgée de 32 ans. Elle est mariée à un Laboratin de profession, et est mère de 1 enfant.  
Yawoa travaille comme revendeuse depuis 2009. Elle achète et revend des bazins riches et moins riches à toutes personnes comme ambulante à Lomé. Elle achète les bazins au grand marché de Lomé 
Yawoa a requis son premier crédit de WAGES afin d’acheter des bazins destinés à la vente.  Elle veut réinvestir ses profits supplémentaires dans le développement de son activité. 
Dans les prochaines années, Yawoa voudrait avoir une boutique de vente de bazins. Elle dit qu’avec les profits, Elle prévoit s’assurer une autonomie financière.
texts.en:
Yawoa is a 32-year-old woman. She is married to a laboratory assistant, and is the mother of one child.

Yawoa has been working as a retail merchant since 2009. She buys and resells rich (100% cotton) and less rich bazin fabric, to all-comers as an itinerant vendor in Lomé. She buys bazin fabric at Lomé's great market.

Yawao requested her first loan from WAGES to purchase bazin fabric to be resold. She wants to reinvest any additional profits into developing more business.

In coming years, she would like to have a shop selling bazin. She said that with the profits, she plans to ensure her financial autonomy.

loans.use: Buy lengths of bazin fabric
